items.description: Tourists are stranded in towns dotted across north-west Queensland as rain continues to keep major rivers in flood.

items.description: Four Hindu men have been killed in Muslim-majority Bangladesh in just over two weeks, and several houses have been burned, leaving the minority community traumatised and fearing for their lives.

items.title: Australian brands still dealing with 'the wild west' of Trump's tariffs
items.description: From de minimis to beef tariffs, Aussie exporters are preparing for another "wild" year.

items.title: US capture of Maduro draws international condemnation

featured_image.name: U.S. strikes on Venezuela spark alarm across Latin America and beyond

items.description:
World leaders expressed deep concern and sharp divisions over the US military operation in Venezuela on Saturday, with the United Nations and major powers condemning the strikes as a dangerous violation of international law while some regional allies celebrated the capture of President Nicolás Maduro.

UN Secretary-General António Guterres said he was "deeply alarmed" by the overnight operation, warning that "these developments constitute a dangerous precedent," according to his spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric[1][2]. Guterres emphasized "the importance of full respect—by all—of international law, including the UN Charter" and expressed concern that "the rules of international law have not been respected"[1][3]. Venezuela has requested an emergency meeting of the UN Security Council[1][2].

items.title: Amid a population crisis, this island needs migrants to keep its industry alive
items.description: The Japanese island of Etajima's oyster industry relies almost entirely on foreign workers due to its aging population.

items.title: European advisers back $740B Ukraine aid plan

featured_image.name: European Union approves over $105 billion toward Ukraine aid ...

items.description:
National security advisers from across Europe convened in Kyiv on Saturday to advance a US-led peace proposal and coordinate international support for Ukraine, marking a pivotal moment in diplomatic efforts to end Russia's nearly four-year war.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said the talks achieved progress on three fronts: security guarantees, reconstruction, and "a basic framework for a real rebuilding."[1] Representatives from Canada, NATO, and over a dozen European nations participated in the high-level discussions, which Ukraine's chief negotiator Rustem Umerov described as focusing on "security and economic issues, work on framework documents, and coordination of further steps with partners."[2][3]

items.title: Is butter, margarine or nut spread the best choice?
items.description: You might have a personal preference for which spread you use at home, but experts say there are health considerations for which one you use.

items.title: America's 250th birthday party will serve up a toxic brew of exceptionalism
items.description: It is entirely fitting that the US is so splintered on its semiquincentennial. Division, for the lion's share of its history, has been its default.

items.title: Trump says US will govern Venezuela after Maduro capture

featured_image.name: Live: Trump says US will run Venezuela after Maduro's 'capture'

items.description:
President Donald Trump declared Saturday that the United States would govern Venezuela until a safe transition could be organized, marking an unprecedented assertion of American control over a sovereign nation in the Western Hemisphere following a dramatic overnight military operation that captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro[1][2][3].

"We're going to run the country until such time as we can do a safe, proper and judicious transition," Trump said at a press conference at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida[1][3]. "So we don't want to be involved with having somebody else get in, and we have the same situation that we had for the last long period of years."

items.title: Trump says US 'will run' Venezuela after strikes
items.description: The US has "captured" Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife during an early-morning raid, which saw US military strike targets within the capital Caracas and in several other states. Follow live.

items.title: Maduro and wife indicted on narco-terrorism charges

featured_image.name: Venezuela's Maduro begins new term as US increases bounty for his arrest

items.description:
US Attorney General Pam Bondi announced Saturday that Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife Cilia Flores have been indicted in the Southern District of New York on multiple charges including narco-terrorism conspiracy, cocaine importation, and weapons offenses[1][2][3]. The announcement came hours after President Donald Trump confirmed that US forces had captured the couple following a large-scale military strike on Venezuela early Saturday morning[4][5][6].

"They will soon face the full wrath of American justice on American soil in American courts," Bondi wrote on social media[1][2][7]. The charges against Maduro include narco-terrorism conspiracy, cocaine importation conspiracy, possession of machine guns and destructive devices, and conspiracy to possess such weapons against the United States[2][3][6]. While specific charges against Flores were not detailed in Bondi's statement, the attorney general thanked Trump "for having the courage to demand accountability on behalf of the American People"[7][8].

items.title: Trump claims Maduro captured after US strikes Caracas

featured_image.name: U.S. launches military strikes on Venezuela as Trump escalates pressure on Maduro regime, sources say

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced early Saturday that the United States successfully captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife following military airstrikes on Caracas, though the claim could not be independently verified as of Saturday morning.

"The United States of America has successfully carried out a large scale strike against Venezuela and its leader, President Nicolas Maduro, who has been, along with his wife, captured and flown out of the Country," Trump wrote on Truth Social[1][2][3][4]. The operation was conducted "in conjunction with U.S. Law Enforcement," and Trump said he would hold a press conference at 11 a.m. at his Mar-a-Lago estate[1][2].

items.title: Trump orders US military strikes on Venezuela

featured_image.name: US Flexes Military Muscles at Venezuela

items.description:
Multiple explosions rocked Venezuela's capital Caracas in the early hours of Saturday as President Trump ordered military strikes on Venezuelan military facilities, marking a dramatic escalation in Washington's pressure campaign against the Maduro regime[1][2][3].

At least seven explosions were heard around 2 a.m. local time, accompanied by low-flying aircraft and power outages in several neighborhoods, according to witnesses and international reporting[4][5][3]. The strikes targeted key military installations including Fuerte Tiuna, Venezuela's largest military complex, and La Carlota Air Base in eastern Caracas[5][6][7]. Reports also indicated strikes on El Libertador Air Force Base in Maracay, a strategic hub for Venezuela's air force[6][8].

items.title: 2025 ranked among three hottest years on record

featured_image.name: 2025 was one of three hottest years on record, scientists say

items.description:
Scientists confirmed Friday that 2025 was among the three hottest years ever recorded globally while the United Kingdom experienced its warmest and sunniest year since measurements began, marking a milestone in the accelerating climate crisis as the three-year temperature average exceeded the Paris Agreement's 1.5°C warming threshold for the first time[1][2][3][4][5].

The Met Office reported the UK's mean temperature reached 10.09°C in 2025, surpassing the previous record of 10.03°C set in 2022[3][4][5]. The reading makes 2025 only the second year since 1884 that the UK's annual temperature has topped 10°C, and places four of the last five years in the top five warmest on record[3][4][5]. The UK also recorded 1648.5 hours of sunshine, 61.4 hours more than the previous record set in 2003[4][6].

Globally, 2025 ranked as one of the three hottest years recorded, joining 2023 and trailing 2024, which the World Meteorological Organization confirmed in January as the warmest year at 1.55°C above pre-industrial levels[2][7][8]. More concerning to climate scientists, the three-year period from 2023 to 2025 marked the first time the running temperature average broke through the 1.5°C threshold established in the 2015 Paris Agreement[2][9][10][11].

items.title: Gold surges as Trump warns Iran amid 2026 market uncertainty

featured_image.name: Wall Street Sees Another Banner Year for Markets. Could Anything Stop It?

items.description:
As 2026 begins, investors and policymakers are confronting a landscape defined by elevated geopolitical tensions and divergent economic forecasts, with Asia caught between U.S. policy unpredictability and Middle Eastern instability that sent gold surging above $4,300 per ounce on the year's first trading day.

Escalating U.S.-Iran tensions dominated early market sentiment, with President Donald Trump issuing a "locked and loaded" warning on January 2 following massive protests in Iran sparked by inflation exceeding 42%[1]. The rhetoric rekindled fears of direct military conflict after U.S. and Israeli forces reportedly struck Iranian nuclear facilities in June 2025, pushing investors toward safe-haven assets[1]. Meanwhile, experts warn that the Middle East's "armed peace" remains fragile, with analysts at SpecialEurasia assessing that the region faces "high-probability" prospects of renewed Israeli-Iranian conflict in early 2026[2].

items.title: Iran protests spread to 50 cities, leaving 7 dead

featured_image.name: Five things you need to know about protests in Iran

items.description:
Iran is confronting its most serious wave of unrest since 2022, as demonstrations that began over economic grievances have rapidly evolved into open defiance of the country's theocratic leadership. The protests, now in their sixth day, have spread to at least 50 cities and resulted in at least seven deaths in clashes with security forces[1][2][3][4][5].

What started December 28 as merchants striking over a currency crisis has transformed into a nationwide uprising. Demonstrators are chanting "Death to the dictator" and "Mullahs must leave Iran," directly targeting Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei with an intensity not seen since the protests following Mahsa Amini's death in 2022[1][6][7].

The unrest reached a critical turning point when protests spread to Qom, Iran's clerical stronghold and the ideological heart of the Islamic Republic. Videos from the holy city showed demonstrators fighting back against security forces and chanting slogans calling for the clergy's removal, representing a profound symbolic blow to the regime[6][8][7].

items.title: Memory chip prices surge as AI demand strains supply

featured_image.name: The AI frenzy is driving a memory chip supply crisis

items.description:
As the tech industry prepares to converge on Las Vegas for CES 2026 starting January 6, two critical forces are reshaping the computing landscape: an unprecedented race to build AI infrastructure and a memory chip shortage driving prices to historic highs.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang and AMD CEO Lisa Su will deliver back-to-back keynotes on January 5, setting the tone for an event expected to showcase how artificial intelligence is transforming data centers, consumer devices, and the global semiconductor supply chain[1][2][3][4].
